notes.heading: First Law of Thermodynamics
notes.summary: States that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed; the change in internal energy equals heat added to the system minus work done by

notes.heading: Second Law of Thermodynamics
notes.summary: Introduces the concept of entropy; states that in any energy transfer, the total entropy of an isolated system can never decrease over time.

notes.heading: Carnot Cycle
notes.summary: A theoretical thermodynamic cycle that defines the maximum efficiency possible; consists of isothermal and adiabatic processes.

notes.heading: Heat Engines
notes.summary: Devices that convert thermal energy into work; characterized by efficiency, which measures how much of the input heat is converted to work.

notes.heading: Refrigerators and Heat Pumps
notes.summary: Devices that transfer heat from a cooler to a warmer area, using work; coefficients of performance are used to define efficiency.

notes.heading: Thermodynamic Processes
notes.summary: Includes various forms like isobaric, isochoric, isothermal, and adiabatic processes that describe how a system evolves thermally and mechanically.

notes.heading: Enthalpy
notes.summary: A thermodynamic quantity representing the total heat content of a system, useful for accounting for heat transfer at constant pressure.

notes.heading: Gibbs Free Energy
notes.summary: Determines the spontaneity of a process at constant temperature and pressure; if G is negative, the process occurs spontaneously.

notes.heading: Phase Changes
notes.summary: Describes transitions between solid, liquid, and gas phases; involves latent heat and can be represented in phase diagrams.
